allQuestions.description: More than 600,000 Canadians served in the war, most of them volunteers, out of a total population of eight million.

allQuestions.question: When must federal elections be held?

alternatives.1: Whenever the Prime Minister calls the election

alternatives.3: When the MPs want a new Prime Minister

alternatives.4: On the third Monday in October every four years following the most recent general election

allQuestions.description: Under legislation passed by Parliament, federal elections must be held on the third Monday in October every four years following the most recent general election.

allQuestions.question: Which phrase embodied the vision of building a powerful, united, wealthy and free country that spanned a continent?

alternatives.1: The nation of the free and powerful

alternatives.2: Dominion from sea to sea and from the river to the end of the earth

alternatives.3: Dominion from ocean to ocean to the end of the world

alternatives.4: Oh Canada, my home and native land

allQuestions.description: Sir Leonard Tilley, an elected official and Father of Confederation from New Brunswick, suggested the term Dominion of Canada in 1864. He was inspired by Psalm 72 in the Bible which refers to "dominion from sea to sea and from the river to the ends of the earth."

allQuestions.question: What safeguards your rights and freedoms?

alternatives.1: The Charter of Rights and Freedoms

allQuestions.description: The Constitution of Canada was amended in 1982 to entrench the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, which begins with the words, "Whereas Canada is founded upon principles that recognize the supremacy of God and the rule of law." This phrase underlines the importance of religious traditions to Canadian society and the dignity and worth of the human person.

allQuestions.question: Which party forms the new government following a federal election?

alternatives.1: The political party with the most seats in the House of Commons

alternatives.2: the political party that the Queen chooses

alternatives.3: The political party that has at least 40% of the seats in the House of Commons

alternatives.4: The Governor General proposes legislation that will allow elected officials to form the new government

allQuestions.description: Ordinarily, after an election, the leader of the political party with the most seats in the House of Commons is invited by the Governor General to form the government.

allQuestions.question: In a federal election, who do Canadians vote for?

alternatives.1: A candidate whom they want to represent them in Parliament

alternatives.2: All candidates in their electoral district

alternatives.3: The most effective public speaker in charge of the election campaign

alternatives.4: Someone to become the Premier of the province

allQuestions.description: The citizens in each electoral district elect one MP who sits in the House of Commons to represent them, as well as all Canadians.

allQuestions.question: When was Confederation?
allQuestions.description: Canada has been a constitutional monarchy in its own right since Confederation in 1867 during Queen Victoria's reign.

allQuestions.question: Which of the following is a federal government responsibility?
allQuestions.description: In our federal state, the federal government takes responsibility for matters of national and international concern. These include defence, foreign policy, interprovincial trade and communications, currency, navigation, criminal law and citizenship.

allQuestions.question: What is an "electoral district"?

alternatives.1: A geographical area where the politicians reside

alternatives.3: A geographical area represented by a member of Parliament (MP)

allQuestions.description: Canada is divided into 308 electoral districts, also known as ridings or constituencies. An electoral district is a geographical area represented by a member of Parliament (MP).

allQuestions.question: What is the capital of Canada?
allQuestions.description: Ottawa: The Capital of Canada

allQuestions.question: Prairie Provinces includes?

alternatives.3: New Brunswick, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island

allQuestions.description: Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta are the Prairie Provinces, rich in energy resources and some of the most fertile farmland in the world.

allQuestions.question: Which province is the most easterly point in North America?
allQuestions.description: Newfoundland and Labrador is the most easterly point in North America and has its own time zone.

allQuestions.question: What are the provinces of Central Canada?
allQuestions.description: More than half the people in Canada live in cities and towns near the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River in southern Quebec and Ontario, known as Central Canada and the industrial and manufacturing heartland.

allQuestions.question: Which of the following is Canada's most populous province?
allQuestions.description: At more than 12 million, the people of Ontario make up more than one-third of Canadians.

allQuestions.question: What attracted thousands of miners to the Yukon during the 1890s?

alternatives.1: The opportunity to make money building the Yukon Railway

alternatives.4: The opportunity to make money building the Pacific Railway

allQuestions.description: Thousands of miners came to the Yukon during the Gold Rush of the 1890s, as celebrated in the poetry of Robert W. Service. Mining remains a significant part of the economy.

allQuestions.question: What is the name given to a descendant of a French colonist from the Maritime Province?
allQuestions.description: The Acadians are the descendants of French colonists who began settling in what are now the Maritime provinces in 1604.

allQuestions.question: Which of the following best represents the tight relationship between Canada and the United States?

alternatives.1: The Peace Arch in Blaine, Washington

alternatives.2: State of Liberty in New York

alternatives.3: International Peace Garden crossing between Canada and the United States

allQuestions.description: At Blaine in the State of Washington, the Peace Arch, inscribed with the words "children of a common mother" and "brethren dwelling together in unity," symbolizes our close ties and common interests.

allQuestions.question: When did the modern energy industry in Canada start?

alternatives.3: Since the discovery of oil in Alberta in 1947

allQuestions.description: The discovery of oil in Alberta in 1947 began Canada's modern energy industry.

allQuestions.question: What does GATT stand for?

alternatives.1: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade

alternatives.2: General Agreement on Traffic and Transportation

alternatives.3: Government Agreement on Tariffs and Trade

alternatives.4: Government Agreement on Treasure and Trust

allQuestions.description: The world's restrictive trading policies in the Depression era were opened up by such treaties as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), now the World Trade Organization (WTO).

allQuestions.question: Who was the first woman Member of Parliament?
allQuestions.description: In 1921 Agnes Macphail, a farmer and teacher, became the first woman MP.

allQuestions.question: In honour of which was the Peace Tower built?

alternatives.4: The Battle of the Plains of Abraham

allQuestions.description: The Peace Tower was completed in 1927 in memory of the First World War.

allQuestions.question: Who was Dr. Emily Stowe?

alternatives.1: The first Canadian woman to practise medicine in Canada and founder of suffrage movement in Canada

alternatives.3: The first leader of the Liberal Party

alternatives.4: The first Canadian hockey player to play in the United States and the originator of the suffrage movement in the United States

allQuestions.description: The effort by women to achieve the right to vote is known as the women's suffrage movement. Its founder in Canada was Dr. Emily Stowe, the first Canadian woman to practise medicine in Canada.

allQuestions.question: In 1939, Canada joined forces with its democratic allies to combat?
allQuestions.description: The Second World War began in 1939 when Adolf Hitler, the National Socialist (Nazi) dictator of Germany, invaded Poland and conquered much of Europe. Canada joined with its democratic allies in the fight to defeat tyranny by force of arms.

allQuestions.question: To date, how many Canadians have killed in wars?
allQuestions.description: Canadians wear the red poppy and observe a moment of silence at the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month to honour the sacrifices of over a million brave men and women who have served, and the 110,000 who have given their lives.

allQuestions.question: During the War of 1812, who was the Canadian heroine who warned James FitzGibbon of an impending American attack?
allQuestions.description: In 1813, Laura Secord, pioneer wife and mother of five children, made a dangerous 19-mile (30-km) journey on foot to warn Lieutenant James FitzGibbon of a planned American attack. Her bravery contributed to victory at the Battle of Beaver Dams. She is recognized as a heroine to this day

allQuestions.question: What is the location of Canada's largest naval base?
allQuestions.description: As Canada's largest east coast port, deep-water and ice-free, the capital, Halifax, has played an important role in Atlantic trade and defence and is home to Canada's largest naval base.

allQuestions.question: Who were the "Bluebirds"?

alternatives.1: Nurses whom served in the Royal Canadian Army Medical Corps, many of them overseas

alternatives.3: Canadian Forces Reserves (militia), responsible to defend the north

allQuestions.description: More than 3,000 nurses, nicknamed "Bluebirds," served in the Royal Canadian Army Medical Corps, 2,500 of them overseas

allQuestions.question: In 1604 who were the first French explorers to establish a settlement north of Florida?

alternatives.1: Pierre de Monts and Samuel de Champlain

alternatives.2: Pierre de Monts and Jean Talon

alternatives.3: Jean Talon and Sir George-Étienne Cartier

alternatives.4: Sir George-Étienne Cartier and Sir Louis-Hippolyte La Fontaine

allQuestions.description: In 1604, the first European settlement north of Florida was established by French explorers Pierre de Monts and Samuel de Champlain, first on St. Croix Island (in present-day Maine), then at Port-Royal, in Acadia (present-day Nova Scotia).

allQuestions.question: What is the name of the location where Champlain built a fortress in 1608?
allQuestions.description: In 1608 Champlain built a fortress at what is now Québec City.

allQuestions.question: What did Canada form with other democratic Western countries during the Cold War?

alternatives.2: The North American Aerospace Defence Command

allQuestions.description: Canada joined with other democratic countries of the West to form the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), a military alliance, and with the United States in the North American Aerospace Defence Command (NORAD).

allQuestions.question: Who invented the first electric light bulb?

alternatives.4: Reginald Fessenden and Sir Sandford Fleming

allQuestions.description: Matthew Evans and Henry Woodward — together invented the first electric light bulb and later sold the patent to Thomas Edison who, more famously, commercialized the light bulb.
